bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Estanislao Pardo Figueroa, November 26, 1921

div1.p: Hanson refers to the Academy of Medicine meeting to study epidemics of yellow fever. He rebuts the contention of a Peruvian physician to the absence of yellow fever in the area, noting that the goal of the campaign is to insure against recurrence.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Estanislao Pardo Figueroa, November 26, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION
DE LA
CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
Contra la Fiebre Amarilla
EN LOS
Departamentos del Norte
----
TRUJILLO
--
Hanson
Trujillo,
November 26, 1921.
Dr. Estanislao Pardo Figueroa,
President of the Academy of Medicine,
Lima, Perú.
My Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I wish to express to you my appreciation of the
courtesy which you extended in inviting me to attend the sessions
of the Academy of Medicine for the purpose of studying the epi-
demics of yellow fever in Peru.

It is very gratifying to me and to the other Physicians
who have labored in these campaigns to note the interest taken
by the Academy for the purpose of arriving at the true nature of
the epidemics in the Departments of the North during the last
two years and a half. I was very much interested in
hearing the view point of Dr. Julian Arce in regard to the matter.
I had heard from many different sources that he did not believe
that we were dealing with yellow fever, and it had aroused a
great deal of curiosity in my mind to know on what grounds he
based his arguments. While I think I obtained his viewpoint in
the three session which I attended, I still regret that I could
not attend them all. His review of the history of yellow fever
and his discussion of the recent epidemics was very interesting
indeed, and I wish to further express my grateful appreciation
to Dr. Arce for his courtesy in concluding his discussions before
I sailed for the north.

The object of this letter is to, if possible, explain
certain points which he referred to, on which it appears that he
has received incorrect information; also to add certain
data for the convenience of the Academy of Medicine in case this
honourable body desires to further consider the matter.

It is interesting to note that Dr. Arce considers the
existence to two distinct types of black water fever (fiebre
biliosa hemoglobinurica) due to different etiological agents,
and that one of these apperrs in epidemics and confers immunity
to subsequent attacks, while the other it seems he accepts as the black
water fever of malarious sections and as due to the untoward
effects of chronic malaria especially in tropical countries where
there is a relatively large amount of pernicious malaria. the pernicious
type of this diseases

In regard to black water fever I wish to say that we
have seen no cases of this type among the patients observed by
the Medical Staff of the Sanitary campaigns against yellow fever
during the last two years and a half. In none of the cases ob-
served and included in our statistics has there been any case
with either intermitent or continuous “black water” urine or of with
urine of the color of port wine. Such a striking clinical mani-
2. Dr. Estanislao Pardo Figueroa, November 26, 1921.
festation would have received the careful attention of all the
medical officers of the campaign, and would have been received
with welcome as an evidence that it were unnecessary to continue
our campaign. The urines of all the cases which figure in the
statistics of the oficially confirmed cases were carefully
observed for any such evidences of hemoglobinuria, and as I
have stated in none were they found.

Furthermore if the casesthere observed by us in this epidemic
or better said in these epidemics, were cases of biliosa hemoglo-
binuria, why have they disappeared with the disappearance of the
stegomya mosquito (Aedes Calopus, more recently designated as the
Aedes Argentis)?

As you know there were a great many cases of black water
fever in Panama in the district of the Canal Zone during the early
days both before and after the yellow fever was eradicated from
that territory. The yellow fever made its last appearance in
Panama (i.e., with in the territory designated as the Canal Zone
and the cities of Panama and Colon) in the year 1905, but cases
of black water fever continued presenting themselves until recent
years or until the malaria index was very markedly reduced, show-
ing for Panama a very evident relationship between the malaria
index and black water fever, but none between yellow fever and
black water fever. Hence in Panama and there was no relationship
between the stegomya index and and cases of “biliosa hemoglobin-
urica” while there distinctly was between the anopheles index
and black water fever.

In consulting our statistics for the epidemics in Perú
from July 1919 to the last cases seen by us in July 1921, it
will be seen that the epidemics have attacked with preference
young people and foreigners. Almost without exception all cases
over 25 years of age have been foreigners or people recently
arrived from the mountain districts. Such facts are in full
harmony with the epidemiology of yellow fever. Furthermore
among the foreigners who have arrived and who have previously
had yellow fever no one has been attacked even though they have
been quite extensively exposed while on the other hand all the
foreigners none-immune to yellow fever who have been extensively
exposed have been attacked by the fever. Of all persons attacked
by the fever in the recent epidemics none have had a second
attack.

In consulting the blue-print of the graphic chart of
the campaign in the Department of Lambayeque you will see the
definite relationship between the number of sick and the per-
centage of stegomya breeding. In this chart there are no cases of yellow
fever shown of fever after the Stegomya index has remaind low for a
sufficient time to have eliminated the adult infected mosquito.
In such a case in order to say that this epdemic has been one
of black water fever, or “fiebre biliosa homoglobinurica” one
would have to prove that the Stegomya is also the vector of the
infection of the matter disease which is still unproven. to be proven.
3. Dr. Estanislao Pardo Figueroa, November 26, 1921.

In justice to Dr. Henry R. Carter, Assistant Surgeon
General of the United States Public Health Service, and member
of the Yellow Fever Committee of the International Health
Board of the Rockefeller Foundation, I can say that he did not
consider the yellow fever to have been endemic in the coast
of Perú, but even if he had he is a person of sufficient ex-
perience and training in both yellow fever and malaria to be
quite competent to distinguish between the two. It is possible
that Dr. Arce may have been mislead in his reference to Dr.
Carter on account of the unfounded statements of Dr. Mariano
Pagador, who made very disparaging remarks in connection with
Dr. Carter's proceedure in the examination of cases in Ferreñafe.
Dr. Pagador never saw Dr. Carter or myself examine a single case
and never discussed or conversed with Dr. Carter about the matter
of yellow fever in any form whatsoever.

In reference to the requirement of Dr. Arce that the
route of introduction of the yellow fever into Peru be proven
I wish to say that in so far as I and the other physicians who
have studied the recent epidemics are concerned, this has been
satisfactorily demonstrated. Still I consider this an unnecessary
essential in establishing the diagnosis of yellow fever. Suchx
It has been common knowledge that yellow fever existed in
Guayaquil continuously up to the time of the announcement of the
epidemic in Piura in June 1919, and the person who has investiga-
ted the travel and means of communication between Ecuador and
the northern province of Perú can only explain the absence of the
fever from Perú on the grounds that the former epidemics, in
1894-95-96 and 97, left the population in the northern provinces
immune, and a new outbreak could not occur until the increase in
a sufficient non-immune population to allow a new general out-
break. However the studies made by Dr. M.J. Quiroz in the Province
of Tumbes are quite clear and convincing of the presence of
yellow fever in that section before the epidemic in the Depart-
ment of Piura in 1919. Dr. Quiroz has presented this so fully and
so well that it is useless for me to discuss it.

Finally Dr. Julian Arce states in summing up his very
interesting and instructive discourse, that he considers it
essential to take the word of the Physicians in regard to the
diagnosis inpreference to that of “curanderos e empiricos” and
on this basis attempts to refute the facts presented by Dr.
Quiroz. In this connection he cites DR. Reinoso, Dr. Zuniga, Dr.
Angosto and Dr. Valcarcel. In so far as Dr. Zuniga is concerned
he at first denied the presence of yellow fever and then later
during the height of the epidemic in Paita saw and diagnosed
about half of the cases in Paita. Dr. Reinoso declared himself
in the Prefectura in Piura as convinced that the cases we were
discussing were undoubted cases of yellow fever. Dr. Angosto
I know nothing about- it may be possible that the cases seen
by him may have been cases of malaria or “fiebre biliosa hemo-
globinurica”. But in so far as Dr. Valcarcel“ Médico Sanitario
4. Dr. Estanislao Pardo Figueroa, November 26, 1921.
Departamental” for the Department of Piura in 1919 and 1920,
is concerned I wish to say that Dr. Valcarcel in our first con-
ference in the Prefectura in Piura accepted the diagnosis of
yellow fever, then in the street he denied it, later he reitera-
ted to me and to Dr. Quiroz in the presence of Mr. Hope of the
Duncan Fox Co., that it was and later again denied it and
finally while he was in Sechura in February and March of 1920
he was the first Physician to announce the presence of yellow
fever in that place. Hence it seems to me that it is difficult
for a scientific body like the Academy of Medicine of Lima, to
place any reliance on these men who have contradicted themselves
in this manner. The other Physician in Piura who denied the
diagnosis was Dr. Cueva and he was consistent in his denial, but
I was informed that as soon as the diagnosis was established he
took all possible precautions to protect himself and family against
infection. Also another point before closing this portion of the
discussion. Dr. Valcarcel never took any active part in the Cam-
paign in Morropon, this epidemic was under the control of Dr. Ri-
cardo Mendoza M., and Dr. Enrique Caballero, two very sincere and
competent professionals.

In Piura the diagnosis was confirmed by Dr. Prieta, Dr.
Gonzales, Dr. Guzman, Dr. Lituma, Dr. Marcos Vega, Dr. M.J. Quiroz and
in addition by a Sr. Saona who had worked a long time in the
yellow fever hospitals in Guayaquil. In addition the diagnosis
was confirmed by Dr. Reinoso to whom Dr. Arce refers. Later the
diagnosis was confirmed for other sections of the Department by
Dr. Enrique Caballero, Ricardo Mendoza M., Benjamin Zapata, Chiri,
Meldonada, Cruz, Victor Dies Canseco, Dr. Corsiglio (who later died
with yellow fever in Paita), General Gorgas, Dr. H.R. Carter and
the writer.

In the Department of Lambayeque the only Physician who
has denied the diagnosis is Dr. Mariano Pagador, and in so far as
I can ascertain this young man had never before seen a case of
yellow fever. The diagnosis in this department was confirmed by
Dr. M.J. Quiroz, and the following physicians, Victor Dies Canseco,
A. Alva Diaz, Julio Benavides, Mayor Carrera, Capitan Seminario,
Ugaz, Rezetto, Agillar, Ponce, Muro Pacheco, Torres of Patapo,
Novoa of Tuman and many others whose names I can not for the
moment recall in addition to Dr. H.R. Carter and the writer.

In the Department of Libertad the only denial was that
of a certain M. Helio Uceda, also a person who never before had
seen a case of yellow fever, but his denial was principally a
denial of the cases in Trujillo. The diagnosis in this Department
was confirmed by all Physicians who saw and treated the cases.
Among these were DR. L.G. Tapia, Dr. Blondet, Velez, Fernandez,
Ortis Silva, Taboada, Arce Davila, Buzzi, Casteneda of Casa Grande,
and others. In the Province of Pacasmayo the disease was denied
by no one, but was confirmed by all who saw the cases such as
Drs. Ricardo Mendoza, Nicolas Cavassa and two. Physicians in San
Pedor whoses names I do not at this moment recall.

In addition to the above we had the pleasure of the
5. Dr. Estanislao Pardo Figueroa, November 26, 1921.
association and cooperation of the distinguished French Mili-
tary Surgeon, Colonel Eduardo Vergne who is a scholar and a
perfect gentleman. Colonel Vergne studied especially the cases
among the troops and has made a publication in the Cronica
Medica of Lima. In this publication the Academy has acces to
the opinions of the Colonel in the matter.

In view of the foregoing it seems that upon the very
grounds which your distinguished colaborator Dr. Julian Arce has
required, namely that one who has not personally studied the
cases in the field is obliged to accept that of the profession
which has made sincere efforts to arrive at the truth in the
matter. In fact one can say that the opinion among the Medical
men both Peruvian and foreign is unanimous among those who have
observed the cases. It does not seem reasonable that the opinion
of those who have not studied any of the cases, or those who have
made denials due to pressure from certain commercial and politi-
cal influences, should be accepted contradicting the opinions of
virtually all the professionals of the the coast to the north of
Lima.

In conclusion I beg to repeat that I am very grateful
for the opportunity of hearing Dr. Julian Arce's views in the
matter and that I respect his opinions, but believe that he has
been incorrectly informed in the matter. I feel quite certain
that if Dr. Arce had come up to Lambayeque and studied the cases
while the epidemic was at its height that he would have gone
back to Lima quite satisfied that it was yellow fever and nothing
else that we were contending with, and that we were actually
rendering a valuable service to the country in the fight which
we carried on so unrelentingly.

Assuring you of my very high esteem and appreciation
for the opportunity of presenting to you this brief statement
of facts about the recent epidemics. As you know the object of
this years campaign is to assure Peru and the Pacific Coast of
South America for all time against the recurrence of this
scourge which has existed from- no one knows what time. It is
for the sake of insuring the successful attainment of this object
that the International Health Board has furnished funds liberally
paying nine tenths of the expenses of the campaign. Naturally if
this well known Institution had not fully convinced themselves
that these epidemics were yellow fever and nothing else they
would not have continued to furnish all funds necessary for the
work.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully submitted, Henry Hanson, M.D.,
Director of the Yellow Fever
Campaign in Perú.
